pullRequest.body:
This defines Codiscrete Categories which are dual to Discrete Categories. We also show the codiscrete functor is right adjoint to the objects functor.

Co-authored-by: [Joël Riou](https://github.com/joelriou)

---

First time contributor. I have two definitions of the adjunction and I wasn't sure which one is best to keep. 
A lot of this file parallels the discrete file, except that they define discrete as a structure and I don't. Wasn't sure how to do it.



[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

@AlvaroRBO, if this is ready for review again, could you remove the `awaiting-author` label, and click "resolve" on all conversations above that you're satisfied with?
After the few suggested modifications are made, I think this PR can be merged.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11757887969/job/32755656876)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11757887969/job/32755656935)
Congrats @AlvaroRBO and thank you @joelriou
Just two very minor suggestions
Just two very minor suggestions

The comment `/-- ... -/` just before a definition is going to appear in the user interface (typically in VSCode) when we hover the pointer over `Codiscrete`: then, as much as possible, we want this to be a description of the definition. In the case of a category, it is nice if we also include a description of the morphisms here:

```suggestion

/-- The type of objects in the category `Codiscrete A` is a type synonym for `A` and there is a unique
morphism between any two objects in this category. -/
```

Usually, we do not need two consecutive blank lines:
```suggestion
```

I believe most mathlib users would not need these comments:
```suggestion
  Hom _ _ := Unit
  id _ := ⟨⟩
```

This definition is a special case of `lift`, then I would suggest defining `funToFunc` in terms of `lift`. `functorOfFun` may be a slightly better name. (At least, I would think the word `functor` should appear in full in the name.)
I would suggest using the name `Codiscrete.functor` so as to keep a certain parallelism with `Discrete.functor`.

@joelriou I agree with the virtue of parallelism but in this case I think "lift" is the better name and functor should refer to the thing that sends a function on types to a functor on codiscrete categories. How would you feel about keeping this terminology here and then changing the terminology used in the discrete categories file? 

Note the discrete file is missing the analogous adjunction. @AlvaroRBO was planning to add this in a separate PR, though if you'd prefer it could be done in this PR.

I think we should not change `Discrete....` definitions because they follows a very good logic (`Discrete.functor`, `Discrete.natTrans`, etc.), and they perfectly abide the naming conventions (`functor` is a functor, `natTrans` is natural transformation, etc).
We may keep `Codiscrete.lift` if there is no better alternative.

Sorry @joelriou I don't mean to be obtuse. One thing that the discrete file doesn't have is a name for the functor from Type.{u} to Cat.{0,u} that constructs the discrete category on a type and the functor between such from a function. What would you call this? (Or, more relevantly, what should @AlvaroRBO call the codiscrete analogue of this?) In other words, what names should be used for the left and right adjoints of `Cat.objects : Cat --> Type`?

Currently, we have very few constructions involving `Cat`. In general, I would suggest putting definitions involving `Cat` in the `Cat` namespace, or writing `Cat` in the names if some definitions are put in another namespace, like `Discrete.functorToCat`. I would reserve short names like `functor`, `natTrans`, etc, for the most basic/lowlevel constructions.
Got it. Thanks for the explanation. As a category theorist, I always default to thinking about Cat, but I can see how that's not the most useful perspective ;)

Arguably, if we chose to define `Discrete A` as a `1`-field structure, we should do the same here. (The overall tendency since the port from lean3 to lean4 has been to introduce more `1`-field structures rather than type synonyms.)

```suggestion
  hom := natTrans
  inv := natTrans
```

This is indeed a definitional equality:
```suggestion
@[simps!]
def natIsoFunctor {F : C ⥤ Codiscrete A} : F ≅ lift (F.obj) := Iso.refl _
```
The `simps` attribute allows the automatic generation of equational lemmas `natIsoFunctor_hom_app` and `natIsoFunctor_inv_app`.

The word `equivalence` should appear in the name, and the `let` block is probably not really necessary:
```suggestion
def oppositeEquivalence (A : Type*) : (Codiscrete A)ᵒᵖ ≌ Codiscrete A where
  functor := lift (fun x ↦ x.unop)
  inverse := (lift (fun x ↦ x.unop)).rightOp
  unitIso := NatIso.ofComponents (fun _ => by exact Iso.refl _)
  counitIso := natIso
```

It would be better to introduce a more universe-generic version:
```lean
def equivFunctorToCodiscrete {C : Type u} [Category.{v} C] {A : Type w} :
    (C → A) ≃ (C ⥤ Codiscrete A) where
  toFun := lift
  invFun F := F.obj
  left_inv _ := rfl
  right_inv _ := rfl
```
and then this can be used in the definition of the adjunction.

```suggestion
    homEquiv_naturality_left_symm := fun _ _ => rfl
    homEquiv_naturality_right := fun _ _ => rfl
```
One construction is enough, but providing equational lemmas for the unit/counit isos of the first definition would be nice.

```suggestion
/-- Unit of the adjunction Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functor -/
```

I would suggest this:
```suggestion
def functorToCat : Type u ⥤ Cat.{0,u} where
```

We should not go into tactic mode when defining data. (There are only a few exceptions which are considered ok.)

For this constructions and other following similar patterns, I would suggest the following:
```lean
def unitApp (C : Type u) [Category.{v} C] : C ⥤ Codiscrete C := lift id

def counitApp (A : Type u) : Codiscrete A → A := Codiscrete.as

lemma adj_unit_app (X : Cat.{0, u}) :
    adj.unit.app X = unitApp X := rfl

lemma adj_counit_app (A : Type u) :
    adj.counit.app A = counitApp A := rfl
```
Then, for example `unitApp` is more universe polymorphic. I would argue that as much as possible, the definitions and lemmas should be done with the more general universes. Then, for defining stuff involving `Cat`, we specialized to the more constrained universe, as it is the case here because of the `0`.
Comment applies to discrete categories!
Try cutting the "by"
Typo: /-- Counit of ... -/

```suggestion
`Codiscrete.functor` promotes a function `f : C → A` (for any category `C`) to a functor `f : C ⥤  Codiscrete A`.
```

```suggestion
/-- Any function `C → A` lifts to a functor `C ⥤ Codiscrete A`.-/
```

```suggestion
/-- The underlying function `C → A` of a functor `C ⥤ Codiscrete A`. -/
```

In mathlib's coding style, the linebreak should be after the infix operator:
```suggestion
    adj.unit.app (functorToCat.obj X) ≫ functorToCat.map (adj.counit.app X) =
      𝟙 (functorToCat.obj X) := rfl
```

```suggestion
def natTrans {F G : C ⥤ Codiscrete A} : F ⟶ G where
  app _ := ⟨⟩

/-- Given two functors into a codiscrete category, the trivial natural transformation is an
natural isomorphism.-/
def natIso {F G : C ⥤ Codiscrete A} : F ≅ G where
```

```suggestion
/-- Components of the unit of the adjunction `Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functorToCat` -/
```

```suggestion
/-- Components of the counit of the adjunction `Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functorToCat` -/
```

```suggestion
 `f : C ⥤ Codiscrete A`.
```

```suggestion
/-- Components of the unit of the adjunction `Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functorToCat`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- Left triangle equality of the adjunction `Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functorToCat`,
as a universe polymorphic statement. -/
lemma left_triangle_components (C : Type u) [Category.{v} C] :
    (counitApp C).comp (unitApp C).obj = id :=
  rfl

/-- Right triangle equality of the adjunction `Cat.objects ⊣ Codiscrete.functorToCat`,
stated using a composition of functors. -/
lemma right_triangle_components (X : Type u) :
    unitApp (Codiscrete X) ⋙ functorOfFun (counitApp X) = 𝟭 (Codiscrete X) :=
  rfl
```

```suggestion
/-- `Codiscrete.functorToCat` turns a type into a codiscrete category-/
```
